etymologies: mid 17th century: from Greek dēmagōgos, from dēmos ‘the people’ + agōgos ‘leading’ (from agein ‘to lead’)

definitions: a political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument

examples.text: a gifted demagogue with particular skill in manipulating the press

shortDefinitions: political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desirest

definitions: (in ancient Greece and Rome) a leader or orator who espoused the cause of the common people

examples.text: the Athenian demagogues had definite and valuable functions within the state

shortDefinitions: (in ancient Greece and Rome) leader or orator who espoused cause of common people

definitions: rhetorically exploit (an issue) for political purposes in a way calculated to appeal to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people

examples.text: he seems more interested in demagoguing the issue in media interviews than in dialogue
they routinely leap to conclusions that are not supported by any evidence and start demagoguing and fearmongering

shortDefinitions: exploit issue in way calculated to appeal to prejudices of ordinary people
